text: Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So we don’t, I don’t think that’s part of their indication. Um, but, you know, we’d have to ask the proton guys for that. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Well then being that the radiation is site specific Doctor: Mm Mmm. Patient: and you’ve created this area- Doctor: Yep. Patient: Why wouldn’t we go site specific in all the other areas that I have- Family Member: You don’t want too much. Too much will kill ya’. Patient: -that you have imaging to know where it is? Doctor: Well, because it doesn’t change the outcome. So your treatment is so that the pain gets better as in kill the cells, no pain. If you have pain elsewhere, you could consider that. But if it’s just a pluck off the areas that you think has cancer, it doesn’t change the overall status of your disease. You know? You don’t live longer with it but you might get some down sides. You know? Like she said the more you radiate the more your bone marrow is hit. So you’ll get a consequence off of that where you might lose some cells. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So you don’t want to treat them unless you know what you’re going to get a result of. So with radiation right now the result is gee I hope my pain is controlled. That’s what I wanted for you. The second one would be gee I hope my pain is controlled and my spine gets stabilized. Whew. And then number three would be I hope the cancer doesn’t come back there. You know? Now it’s been burned out.

text: Family Member: Do they die or are they just inhibited? Doctor: Yeah they like ninety nine percent die then maybe not one hundred precent. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So that’s with the injection. Then there’s a little cylinder, a little flexible cylinder about this long – Patient: Um,hum. Doctor: - that can be implanted under the skin. Patient: Um,hum. Doctor: That lasts for a whole year so that you don’t have to get injections. Some people like that because it’s convenient. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have to go back and forth. But typical most common ways is to get an injection every twelve weeks which is like every three months. Patient: Right. Family Member: And when he does that does he see you at that time?

Doctor: You know, we don't, in this instance zap each one of those because- Doctor: Because it's like one or two. We do zap. Family Member: You do?! Doctor: Yeah, yeah, we do zap. Yeah. Family Member: My creativity works dear. Doctor: There are several things going on at once, zapping one or two won't slow down anything. We only zap-. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: But when you’re on pills like that, experimental ones – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You don’t want to have some big surgery, be scheduled in the middle of it. text: Patient: It’ll go back someday. Doctor: Mm. Patient: Yeah, so. Doctor: Anywho! Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay, here's where we are. Your PSA is six something- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -and it was two something before. So with that rise, I got a little worried. Because I don't want the Xtandi to get away from us. At that point, there was a study and there still is, where people on Xtandi if they start to do this with their PSA, might be eligible to add another pill right on to that. So you still stay on Xtandi. But this other pill might make the Xtandi sort of work better. And, you know, if you were on full dose, you'd be eligible, if you were on three pills, as well as just the two pills a day is still an option. So initially, we weren't sure if it was going to open because this was a study that had a sugar pill arm that I wasn't too keen on. But with this new, kind of like update, everybody gets the pill. So this is where the study is. So here you are in your Xtandi. Xtandi, Xtandi, Xtandi. And then you get randomized. So flip of a coin to either get this new medicine at a certain dose, or this new medicine at the same dose. Okay, so so far, both arms are the same, you just get a new medicine at the same dose, okay, no placebo. This arm is going to keep you like that, so you take the Xtandi plus the new pill at the new dose, no problem, you're just on that. This arm is you on Xtandi plus the new pill, but every month, they're going to try to increase that dose gently. So you get another pill that has more milligrams in it. While that's happening, if you were on this arm, you get a matching placebo. So you do get a sugar pill, but that's in addition to the new pill already being on board. You still with me? Patient: No, you gotta slow down. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to say it again? Patient: Try me again. Doctor: Okay, no worries. Okay, here's you. Patient: Yeah.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Chemo is the only thing that we know right now – the one that your doctor said may not do a whole lot – he doesn’t have much faith in it is what I think what you told me. Is again, we do know that if you get the drug, tolerate the drug, respond to the drug, people live longer, but again, that’s got an if, if, if. Um. So, that would be what usual is, and then this is research, experimental. Would require you coming down here every other week for a couple of weeks. Patient: Ah huh. Doctor: Uh, and then, uh, every two weeks, three weeks, once you get past the first part, you’re here a lot – so that’s for us to watch you, keep close eye on you as well as to see what the side effects are. Uh. But for you, it’s a downside of coming a distance, coming here a lot, feeling tired, feeling fatigued, and with the uncertainty is this going to do anything? Patient: Right. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But again, if you’re driving, folks driving, getting you here, and again you can go out of this world sayin’, “I’ve tried everything ‘till the end.” Okay? But I still think you need to be careful and pay attention to this. Okay? Because if something goes really bad with this – let’s say you get a bad pneumonia, and we want to put you on a breathing machine even though the steroids may be able to bring you back, we don’t know that. But if it gets to a point, you know, I’m not sure you really should be on a breathing machine. Patient: What kind of breathing machine? Doctor: Uh. A ventilator. On TV. Those are television. Your body’s gotten so sick that if I get you to wake up, you still have the bad cancer. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay? So, I also, I mean, I’m not so sure we should be pounding on your chest. Uh, you should be thinking about how far will we go even if it looks bad. (Pause) Patient: No. See, my dad died from prostate cancer in nineteen eighty six. He hadn’t -- didn’t have much treatment at all. Uh. Family Member: He waited, he waited to have severe symptoms. Then he went and then (they’s found)

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
